Literature Review: Second-generation functional data have become increasingly prevalent in various fields, including economics, biology, and finance, due to the growing need to analyze complex, interdependent functional observations. Unlike traditional functional data analysis, which assumes independence of the functions, second-generation functional data require more advanced methods to account for the intricate dependence between the functional observations. This literature review aims to provide an overview of the techniques for analyzing second-generation functional data, with a focus on highlighting the key methodological intricacies that stem from the need for modeling complex dependence. We will discuss the extension of functional principal component analysis (FPCA) to four types of second-generation functional data: multivariate functional data, longitudinal functional data, functional time series, and spatially functional data. We will also explore the applications of FPCA in modeling, prediction, statistical inference, and clustering, and discuss future directions in this area.
